Sect.section:
8
Various font features of the amsmath package

text-unit.text: In the amsmath package \boldsymbol is used for getting individual bold math symbols and bold Greek letters—everything in math except for letters of the Latin alphabet, where you’d use \mathbf. For example,
looks like this:

If a bold version of a particular symbol doesn’t exist in the available fonts, then \boldsymbol can’t be used to make that symbol bold. At the present time, this means that \boldsymbol can’t be used with symbols from the msam and msbm fonts, among others. In some cases, poor man’s bold (\pmb) can be used instead of \boldsymbol:

So-called “large operator” symbols such as
∑
$\sum $
∑
and
∏
$\prod $
∏
require an additional command, \mathop, to produce proper spacing and limits when \pmb is used. For further details see The
TEX
book.
\iint, \iiint, and \iiiint give multiple integral signs with the spacing be­tween them nicely adjusted, in both text and display style. \idotsint gives two integral signs with dots between them.

Some extra over and under arrow operations are provided in the amsmath pack­age. (Basic
LATEX
provides \overrightarrow and \overleftarrow).
These all scale properly in subscript sizes:

Normally you need only type \dots for ellipsis dots in a math formula. The main exception is when the dots fall at the end of the formula; then you need to specify one of \dotsc (series dots, after a comma), \dotsb (binary dots, for binary relations or operators), \dotsm (multiplication dots), or \dotsi (dots after an integral). For example, the input
produces

Double accents:

This double accent operation is complicated and tends to slow down the pro­cessing of a
LATEX
file.

\dddot and \ddddot are available to produce triple and quadruple dot accents in addition to the \dot and \ddot accents already available in
LATEX
:
In the amsmath package \leftroot and \uproot allow you to adjust the position of the root index of a radical:

The command \boxed puts a box around its argument, like \fbox except that the contents are in math mode:

\xleftarrow and \xrightarrow produce arrows that extend automatically to accommodate unusually wide subscripts or superscripts. The text of the sub­script or superscript are given as an optional resp. mandatory argument: Ex­ample:

∑

∑
or
∏
$\prod $
∏

The main use of the command \text is for words or phrases in a display:

The more common math functions such as
log

,

sin
, and
lim
$\lim $

have predefined con­trol sequences: \log, \sin, \lim. The amsmath package provides \DeclareMathOperator and \DeclareMathOperator* for producing new function names that will have the same typographical treatment. Examples:

text-unit.text: can be obtained by typing
Left or right placement of any of the numerators is accomplished by using \cfrac[l] or \cfrac[r] instead of \cfrac.

In amsmath there are optional arguments t and b for the plain
TEX
command \smash, because sometimes it is advantageous to be able to ‘smash’ only the top or only the bottom of something while retaining the natural depth or height. In the formula
𝑋 𝑗 = ( 1 / 𝜆 𝑗 ) 𝑋 𝑗 ′
$X_j=(1/\sqrt {\smash [b]{\lambda _j}})X_j'$
𝑋𝑗=(1/√𝜆𝑗)𝑋′𝑗
\smash[b] has been used to limit the size of the radical symbol.

Without the use of \smash[b] the formula would have appeared thus:
𝑋 𝑗 = ( 1 / 𝜆 𝑗 ) 𝑋 𝑗 ′
$X_j=(1/\sqrt {\lambda _j})X_j'$
𝑋𝑗=(1/√𝜆𝑗)𝑋′𝑗
, with the radical extending to encompass the depth of the subscript
𝑗
$j$
𝑗
.
‘Cases’ constructions like the following can be produced using the cases envi­ronment.

(60) 𝑃 𝑟 − 𝑗 = { 0 if 𝑟 − 𝑗 is odd , 𝑟 ! ( − 1 ) ( 𝑟 − 𝑗 ) / 2 if 𝑟 − 𝑗 is even .
\begin {equation}P_{r-j}= \begin {cases} 0& \text {if $r-j$ is odd},\\ r!\,(-1)^{(r-j)/2}& \text {if $r-j$ is even}. \end {cases}\end {equation}
𝑃𝑟−𝑗={0if 𝑟−𝑗 is odd,𝑟!(−1)(𝑟−𝑗)/2if 𝑟−𝑗 is even.

text-unit.text: To produce a small matrix suitable for use in text, use the smallmatrix environment.

To show the effect of the matrix on the surrounding lines of a paragraph, we put it here:
( 𝑎 𝑏 𝑐 𝑑 )
$\bigl ( \begin {smallmatrix} a&b\\ c&d \end {smallmatrix} \bigr )$
(𝑎𝑏𝑐𝑑)
and follow it with enough text to ensure that there will be at least one full line below the matrix.
\hdotsfor{number} produces a row of dots in a matrix spanning the given number of columns:
The spacing of the dots can be varied through use of a square-bracket option, for example, \hdotsfor[1.5]{3}. The number in square brackets will be used as a multiplier; the normal value is 1.
The \substack command can be used to produce a multiline subscript or su­perscript: for example
produces a two-line subscript underneath the sum:
text-unit.Formula:

\begin {equation}\sum _{\substack {0\le i\le m\\ 0<j<n}} P(i,j)\end {equation}
∑0≤𝑖≤𝑚0<𝑗<𝑛𝑃(𝑖,𝑗)

text-unit.Formula:

\begin {equation}\sum _{\begin {subarray}{l} 0\le i\le m\\ 0<j<n \end {subarray}} P(i,j)\end {equation}
∑0≤𝑖≤𝑚0<𝑗<𝑛𝑃(𝑖,𝑗)

Examples of multiple-line equation structures

text-unit.text: Note: Starting on this page, vertical rules are added at the margins so that the positioning of various display elements with respect to the margins can be seen more clearly.
The split environment is not an independent environment but should be used inside something else such as equation or align.

If there is not enough room for it, the equation number for a split will be shifted to the previous line, when equation numbers are on the left; the number shifts down to the next line when numbers are on the right.

Sect.subsection:
A.5
Align and split within gather

text-unit.text: When using the align environment within the gather environment, one or the other, or both, should be unnumbered (using the * form); numbering both the outer and inner environment would cause a conflict.
Automatically numbered gather with split and align*:
